Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Emergence of Political Careers and Parties, New York 1777-1821

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: As U.S. citizens, we tend to take for granted the existence and operation of electoral parties in the contemporary United States. While they have been the subject of much study, we know very little regarding how modern electoral parties emerged in our history. Focusing on the State of New York, the pivot for the first national party system, this project provides a systematic analysis of the social and political factors that structured the actions of those individuals who built the first parties. The project investigates how they formed networks of political support that spanned across space as well as different levels of government (local, state, federal) and traces how local political elites were pulled into the emerging federal party system. Findings from the project will provide greater insight into the origins of political parties in our democracy, and help to inform our understanding of contemporary political parties through greater detail regarding their evolution. <br/><br/>While political parties were a major concern of scholars across several disciplines, answers to the question of where parties come from are still almost entirely absent. Progress in addressing this question has been stymied in part by the absence of systematic individual-level data. This project approaches the question of party formation through two analyses that include these data. First, because in America the organization of parties was intrinsically bound up with the organization of the state and because creating a state involves office-creation, this project will first reconstruct the structure of the larger system of offices that political elites had to navigate. The project will construct a novel database of all civil, judicial, and military offices from the federal to the state and local level from 1777 to 1821 in the state of New York. Using mobility tables, vacancy chain and sequence analysis, the project investigates the emergence of political careers as meaningful sequences of offices held by individuals. This forms the backdrop for the second analysis. For a subset of 730 political elites who were active during the crucial years between the Constitutional Convention and the election of 1800, the project adds information on party affiliation, socio-demographic characteristics, and the multiple social networks in which they were embedded. Using this comprehensive dataset, the project employs a regression framework to study the factors that determined which political elites affiliated with which party. Findings from this project will inform theories of democracy and its evolution, as well as provide an important historical portrait of individual political careers at a critical time in the development of our nation.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We tend to take for granted the existence and operation of electoral parties in contemporary democracies. But where do political parties come from? Even though the founders of political sociology situated parties at the center of political life, and this field has recently renewed its interest in the study of political parties, we still know very little about how modern electoral parties emerged. We address this lacuna with a systematic analysis of party builders. We conceptualize parties as a new logic of political action and investigate both the social and political factors that make possible and shape these actions. More generally, we study the emergence of a new political field – a party system both in terms of organizations and divisions in the polity – which becomes increasingly organized by parties. To do this, we pay close attention to the relationship between local political structures and the emerging national system of government. 

At the core of the project is the construction of an electronic text database that consists of three files. The first file contains information on political office-holding in the State of New York between 1777 and 1822. The second file contains individual-level and social network data on approximately 750 New York politicians who were active between 1788 and 1801. The third file contains roll calls taken in the New York State Assembly from 1788 to 1803. These data will allow scholars to extend existing work by historians, political scientists, and political sociologists who have studied the formation of political parties after the War of Independence. In addition to party formation, the database will allow researchers to study a range of questions related to the structure of political careers during the early republic. Our database on office-holding is the first of its kind for this early time period; no systematic analyses exist of political careers around the time of the formation of the new nation. Equipped with a range of new methodological tools, our project allows us to return to old questions about the nexus between parties, state formation, and democracy in America in new ways. 

Although the answers produced by our research project are still only tentative, we find a well-developed and surprisingly modern party system in the State of New York as early as the 1790s. This has implications for how we think about the formation of the first parties in American history. Theories that tend to focus on broad social categories such as class or region prove insufficient. The two parties that had taken shape in New York cannot be understood as the politicization of such already exiting social master categories, but were the product of a political process that divided political elites and forced them to increasingly mobilize non-elites. Parties formed around the organizational challenges of mobilizing voters, recruiting cadre, rewarding friends, and jockeying for positions. The latter involved both gaining control over particular appointments in the state and shaping particular legislation. Parties in the legislature were never so organized as when they fought over procedural issues that set the rules of fighting itself. Further, while most scholars assume a top-down process whereby parties originated at the national level and then trickled down, we show that party formation was much more about aligning and knitting together pre-existing state structures. New York’s party system was linked up with those in other states to produce the first national party system.
